comment.author: 8442333@N05
comment._content: Was she part of the same family as John F. Kennedy?

comment.author: 38120614@N07
comment._content: This picture is really worth a thousand words.  It tells a story of upper class society in Miss Kennedy's attire and her own dog.  Even female idols of today have so called "designer dogs" like Paris Hilton's "tinkerbell."

comment.author: 37390974@N05
comment._content: This photograph exudes the aristocracy of society at the time. Her hat, full-length fur, and dog that she carries as an accessory familiarly channel celebrities today.

comment.author: 8442333@N05
comment._content: I believe her full name was Marian Kennedy. There was an article about this event (the first specialty show given by the American Pomeranian Club) in The New York Times, which took place in the sun parlor of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in New York City on January 10, 1911. 262 dogs took part, and the event featured many wealthy and notable personages. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B07E4DB1331E233A...

comment.author: 8442333@N05
comment._content: It looks like Marian Kennedy was the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Van Rensselaer Kennedy. She was in the New York Times quite a bit beginning in 1910. query.nytimes.com/search/sitesearch?query="marian+ke...

comment.author: 35014516@N03
comment._content: Thanks for the additional information.  We'll update the source data and reload the description.

comment.author: 34482443@N05
comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called PupStylish Pics - Dog Fashion, Dog Style and Dog Design, and we'd love to have this added to the group!

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content:
The Waldorf-Astoria's ivy-littered terrace was a popular venue for cat shows as well. This Bain photo was taken in 1914:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/6399908463/in/photostream]
